title: Missing documentain on what is returned for intersection[With|By]
_(value) docs missing entries for chainable/non-chainable
body:
https://lodash.com/docs#_

At least `_.first` is not specified as either chainable or non-chainable (but `_.last` is).

title: Docs: Fix order of arguments in FP docs [ci skip]
body:
The order of the rearranged arguments is incorrect in the FP guide

Example for `set`:
- Given rearrangement order: `(c, a, b)`
- Original order: `(object, path, value)`
- FP order: `(path, value, object)`, which corresponds to a `(b, c, a)` reordering.

This PR fixes the order of the arguments.

Thanks to @piercers for noticing this!

title: Removing pluck makes extracting a path from a set of objects harder
body:
The removal of pluck from lodash 4 has made things like the following harder:

`var item1 = { a : { b : { c : 'value' }}};`
`var item2 = { a : { b : { c : 'value2' }}};`
`var collection = [item1, item2];`

`_.pluck(collection,['a','b','c']); // => ['value', 'value2']` 

I can see chaining maps, or using map, get and partial as the only ways to achieve the same thing.

Would adding support for paths as well as properties to map be a sensible approach?
If so, would it be possible to get that on the road map, and would a PR be welcome?

title: Backwards incompatible change in _.min not mentioned in changelog
body:
lodash 3.10.1: `_.min([])` -> `Infinity`
lodash 4.3.0: `_.min([])` -> `undefined`

I searched the changelog for both "Infinity" and "_.min" and couldn't find this mentioned.

title: _.toString() definition throws in IE11
body:
In IE11 there is `Symbol` defined with `__proto__` but no `Symbol.prototype`.
So the following code in `_toString` fails when assigning symbolToString because the check condition is wrong.

```
var symbolProto = Symbol ? Symbol.prototype : undefined,
    symbolToString = Symbol ? symbolProto.toString : undefined;
```

Shouldn't it be:
`symbolToString = symbolProto ? symbolProto.toString : undefined;`

title: chore(package): update webpack to version 1.12.14
body: http://greenkeeper.io/

title: Thoughts on how to import parseInt unambiguously?
body:
Hey there,

I've started importing methods from LoDash using ES6 destructuring. Looks something like:

``` js
import { map } from 'lodash';
```

This works great in all scenarios except `parseInt`. If I obtain a reference to the `parseInt` method through destructuring -- ESLint complains that I am not passing a radix to window.parseInt.

Is this a common issue? Is this ambiguous enough that I should just not destructure when wanting to use parseInt, or ?

title: _.find and match
body:
Is there a way to do a partial find based on:

``` json
[
{"name": "John James age 57 likes cars"},
{"name": "Mini Star age 23 likes cats"},
{"name": "Patrick Tagger age 8 likes trucks"}
]
```

where you could `_.find` only by specifying name `John` and `57`?

title: flatten's default isShallow parameter when callback provided doesn't make sense
body:
The default behavior of flatten, when called with a callback and no value for shallow, should be to default to `true` for shallow.

https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/d0c9371c3a9f589d2b7af639514ec916e0d57118#diff-e3b258a6af20e616c3a40e00504bdf66R3372

title: Documentation per module
body:
Hey there,

I understand that it might be slightly tedious to keep up to date, but I'd really like it if there could be documentation per module, as well as having the normal docs.

I find I run into the situation where I'll find a lodash package on npm:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2730609/13208422/8ef53860-d8cd-11e5-82be-c9488d4e3ac3.png)

Because the docs aren't available per module, I then have to navigate to the lodash docs, and do another search for the documentation for that module. Not the biggest deal, but definitely a little time consuming..

Thanks for the great utility library, lodash is awesome!
Thomas

title: countBy / groupBy methods that use ES6 Map instead of an object
body:
Hi,

Would you consider adding similar methods (or adding an option to the current methods) that use an ES6 Map instead of an object, so that the values (keys) don't have to be stringified?

``` js
innerArr = [3, 4]
arr = [1, '2', innerArr]
countBy(arr) // {1: 1, 2: 1, '3,4': 1}
es6MapCountBy(arr) // {1: 1, '2': 1, innerArr: 1}
```

Thanks,
Nuno

title: Feature Request: Ability to skip caching for memoize
body:
Allow skipping caching for memoize, in cases where randomness might be used depending on the function input. My proposal is to skip caching when the resolver returns `_`, like how you specify placeholders for `_.partial`.
### Example use

**TL;DR:** Allow the user to input "random" along with other possible inputs. Only cache if the user did not input "random"

In my scripts, when I allow the user to input a color (eg. for customization), I usually also allow the user to enter "random" to get a random color. However, I also accept multiple color formats (hex, rgb, hsv, hsl) and color manipulation filters (saturate, grayscale, etc.) for input. Because of all the calculations in place, I have the function memoized using this function for the resolver:

``` javascript
function(col) { return /^rand(om)?(;|$)/i.exec(col) ? _.uniqueId() : '>' + col; }
```

However, I'd rather not cache the random values since they're only taking up RAM that will never be read, and I'd also rather not prefix the non-random values (which I do because I scream at the thought of the user deciding to input "random_1", especially since the JavaScript version I target doesn't have symbols).

title: Explain in CONTRIBUTING that +1 is encouraged for feature requests.
body:
Hmm, now I'm confused. I came here to ask you to include this because this is my understanding of your policy from [conversation on Twitter yesterday](https://twitter.com/mccjm/status/700386076880461825). Many projects yell at people for +1'ing issues, so if you don't tell people it's ok a lot of them probably won't do it and the gauge of community interest will be skewed.

But before I submitted I noticed that the whole paragraph on feature requests was just added. I didn't know that before, the timing is a total coincidence. But I noticed that the commit that was merged from the PR adding that paragraph [had this at the end](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/c7727f51e703dd42f933c0f4ce54a2fe5eaea7d3):

>  and leave a comment there if you could find one.

But it's gone from the commit that's in `master` https://github.com/lodash/lodash/commit/b7ae5f088573da15354ead52dddd4383f96daaaa.

Is there a reason that part was removed?

title: Links _.remove and _.pull in the docs.
body: It seems that `_.remove` is confusing people on how it works (https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/1892), so I added a note to its documentation pointing to `_.pull` and a note in `_.pull` pointing to `_.remove`.

title: immutability consistency
body:
I've noticed that quite a lot of the lodash methods mutate the original state e.g. `_.set()`
In the spirit of functional programming can I request that these methods be changed so that they just return a new data structure instead of both returning new data and mutating the original data structure?

lodash is an extremely powerful collection of methods, but this really does let it down

This would be pretty easy to implement (using `_.clone` first in each method to create a local copy), and I'm more than happy to make a start and create a PR.

title: Clarify docs on omitBy about predicate parameters
In v4.5.0 _.create does not create properties from objects with value 1
Uncaught TypeError: _.concat is not a function
body: Getting the  `Uncaught TypeError:_.concat is not a function` in version 4.5.0

title: lodash/fp: _.map() iteratee for objects does not pass in key and collection
body: The iteratee is supposed to be passed (value, key, collection). However, when using lodash/fp I only see (value). Is this because the argument list is capped to one? What is the purpose of the capping?

title: lodash/fp: _.orderBy should have arity of 3
body: I cannot figure out how to specify 'asc' and 'desc' when using _.orderBy with lodash/fp, because it has a fixed arity of 2. It should have an arity of 3.

Repro at http://jsbin.com/fuwagareme/1/edit?html,js,console

I expected the `offset` function to be exist in the merged moment instance.

It seems to only happen when an existing sub-object is added to. Showing this with Moment because that's what tickled the problem for us.

Surfaced in https://github.com/Automattic/wp-calypso/pull/3288

title: _.partial treats string partials as arrays of characters
When merging modified primitive type objects, added properties get dropped
FP-style functions don't accept non-functions as iteratees (Error: func is not a function). Regression?
body:
``` js
const arr = [{score: 1}, {score: 2}];

// This works:
_.map(arr, 'score'); // => [1, 2]

// This doesn't:
_mapFP('score')(arr); // => Error: func is not a function

// Works, but is ugly:
_mapFP(item => item.score)(arr); // => [1, 2]
```

This is a huge regression for me. Using strings/objects for iteratees has been one of the most important lodash features for me.

Now I'm trying to import lodash methods individually in order to minimize distro size. That forces me to replace chaining with `flow`, and `flow` needs FP-style lodash functions.

Compared to chaining, `flow` is a huge hit on readability by itself, and the inability to use objects/strings for iteratees makes it even worse! :sob:  The longer the `flow` chain, the harder it is to read all those callbacks.

Please let FP-style lodash functions accept non-functions as iteratees. If this is planned, please add it to the [roadmap](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Roadmap), mentioning the target version number.

:bow:

title: Throw an error when _.uniq is called with a superfluous argument
body:
I have just spent the last few hours tracing back how did suddenly our database got polluted with duplicate records.

It turns out that between v3 and v4 `_.uniq` was separated to `_.uniq`, `_.uniqBy` and `_.uniqWith`. Our codebase was using `_.uniq(data, 'id')`. The extra argument was neither throwing an error nor supporting the legacy feature.

This looks like something thats easy to overlook. What about throwing an error if function is called with a superfluous argument?

title: True array ordering
body:
I am always surprised in Javascript that `[-1] < [-2]` is true. I would like a method, which did ordering of ints, arrays, lists (and objects?) in a more sensible way.

Then (wanting everything), it would be nice to have `_.sortWith`, to use this new comparator.

title: _.valuesIn({...}) is returning an empty array
body:
**Lodash v4.3.0**

`_.valuesIn({ x: 'y' }) === Array []`

**Tested against the following browsers on OS X (El Capitan):**
- Firefox 43.0.4
- Chrome 48.0.2564.109
- Safari 9.1

The function works as expected in **Lodash v3.10.0**.

title: isMatch does not work as expected.
groupBy, sumBy, etc don't send key/index to iteratee, only value
Errors after upgrade
body:
Hello,

After upgrading lodash from 3.5.0 to 4.3.0 some functions I used desapears : _.pluck, _.contains for example. 
I don't find any portability guides in documentation to help me in my upgrade process.

Can someone help me to get this methods back ?

JM.

title: Documentation site is down
body:
https://lodash.com/docs seems to be down......

`
curl: (7) Failed to connect to lodash.com port 443: Connection refused
`

`
http: error: ConnectionError: ('Connection aborted.', error(61, 'Connection refused'))
`

title: camelCase().capitalize() chain behaviour is different then 3.x
body:
Hi,

in version `3.10.1` (and previous ones as far as I know) the following chain:

``` js
_.chain('john_doe').camelCase().capitalize().value()
```

gave as a result `JohnDoe`. In version `4.3.0` the result is `Johndoe`. If you switch the chain it will be `johnDoe`. Basically the last function applied gives the result. Not sure if it's deliberate or not... Please let me know. And if possible, return the old behaviour?... :smile:

title: _.isError gives unexpected response
Add _.asArray method
body:
I did it!

How should `null` and `undefined` be handled?
Empty array or `[null]`, `[undefined]`?
How about `_.asArray()`?

Resolves #953

title: Deprecation warnings are noisy
body:
I have some projects that depend (either directly or indirectly) on lodash 2. The deprecation warning that was recently introduced is generating noise in `npm install` that may be hiding more important issues. In the indirect case, I can't take action on this deprecation, and in the direct case, taking action on it is very costly and risky (since it involves upgrading old code to accommodate for breaking API changes, with no net win).

I'm not sure if this how important it is to tell people about deprecation of lodash; if there was a bug in it, I would probably have noticed by now, and I'm not very worried about security issues. I would have thought `npm deprecate` is more intended for the case of critical problems with specific releases (in which case you really _do_ want to upgrade).

Any thoughts on this, or workarounds to not have to change code and not get deprecation warnings?

thanks!

title: uniqBy with shorthand produces unexpected results
Lodash standalone using lodash-modularized
body:
Is it possible to use lodash-modularized packages as dependencies on lodash standalone?

Consider a package that uses lodash modules (a.k.a lodash-modularized). Npm could do a great job on dedupe considering the standalone lodash on the user side (npm dedupe or npm v3).

On the frontend it should be a greater issue, but babel-plugin-lodash basically solves the problem there.

title: Contributing.md - Link to enhancement issues
body: Change the link from "closed issues" to "closed issues with enhancement label".

title: Lodash fails to use class methods
_.merge modifies source objects
Add paragraph about making feature requests in docs
body:
I'm seeing plenty of:
- feature requests with people asking if it is okay to annoy @jdalton with a proposal
- poorly documented feature requests
- duplicate feature requests

So I thought it'd be a good idea to write in the docs how feature requests work (it will often not be read in time, but it can't hurt much), the most important point being that they should search for similar proposals in the closed issues (and maybe mentally prepare them to the fact that their issue will be closed).

I'm not sure about the wording, but I think it has its place in the docs.

(Also, I capitalized Lodash wherever I thought was fitting, which I can move to another PR)

title: Using _.invert() on Maps?
cloneDeep performance
body:
Compared to other clone packages or a simple `JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(o))`, `_.cloneDeep` is extremely slow. While `JSON` isn't always a good fit (e.g. when copying a function) it's still faster.

Is there anything `_.cloneDeep` is doing that the other implementation doesn't?

title: Undocumented incompatibility from v3 to v4
body:
In Lodash v3, we were using the following functionality (as described [here](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/3.10.1/doc/README.md#example-35))

``` javascript
_.zipObject(['key1', 'value1'],['key2', 'value2'])

// resulting in:
{
  key1: 'value1',
  key2: 'value2'
}
```

but that is incompatible with Lodash v4. It should be `_.fromPairs`:

``` javascript
_.fromPairs(['key1', 'value1'],['key2', 'value2'])
```

Please add this incompatibility to the wiki. Thanks!

title: lodash core's _.has() doesn't work with nested properties
body: From what I observe in lodash core 4.3.0, _.has(object, "prop1.another.prop") doesn't work. I can load the regular copy of has() via 'lodash/has', and that seems to work properly. Anyone else see this?

title: Unexpected behaviour of _.curryRight
body:
If I curry a function which takes 2 arguments, e.g `_.curryRight(func(a, b))`, then create a partial function `funcP` with second argument (i.e expected first argument of new function), then when I call `funcP` again with 2 arguments, it assume those 2 be the original arguments and discard the earlier partial call (for example when using `funcP` in _.map). Expected behaviour is that it would discard extra arguments after it has received `function.length` arguments.

http://jsbin.com/qisohotafa/edit?js,console

Or Is it the expected behaviour of curry in lodash?

title: _.get from lodash/fp doesn’t use defaultValue
body:
I imagine this is because of the automatic transformation from the non-FP version to the FP version, so maybe it is intentional, but my expectation was that `get` from lodash/fp, when invoked with 3 arguments, would be equivalent to the normal `_.get`. Instead, the 3rd argument seems to be ignored, returning `undefined` instead of using the provided defaultValue.

Is this a bug or a known/intentional limitation?

``` js
import normalGet from 'lodash/get';
import { get as functionalGet } from 'lodash/fp';

normalGet({ a: 'b' }, 'c', 'default');     // "default"
functionalGet({ a: 'b' }, 'c', 'default'); // undefined
```

title: _.move(array, fromIndex, toIndex) function
body:
I'd like a function for moving an item in an array.

``` es6
/*
#move - Moves an array item from one position in an array to another.

Note: This is a pure function so a new array will be returned, instead
of altering the array argument.

Arguments:
1. array: Array in which to move an item.           (required)
2. moveIndex: The index of the item to move.        (required)
3. toIndex: The index to move item at moveIndex to. (required)
*/

// Examples
// --------

move(['a', 'b','c'], 2, 0)
// -> ['c', 'a', 'b']

move([{name: 'Fred', name: 'Barney', name: 'Wilma', name: 'Betty'}], 2, 1)
// -> [{name: 'Fred', name: 'Wilman', name: 'Barney', name: 'Betty'}]
```

I hope these submissions aren't annoying. I notice you keep the issues very clean.  If you'd rather I not submit them, let me know.

title: Add a note about in-browser usage of lodash-fp
JSDoc @type annotation
body:
[JSDoc documentation](http://usejsdoc.org/tags-type.html) indicates that `@type` annotation's contents should be wrapped in curly braces. Lodash's JSDoc `@type` annotations are currently without the braces, e.g. for [`isArray`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/4.3.0/lodash.js#L9452):

``` javascript
/**
     * Checks if `value` is classified as an `Array` object.
     *
     * @static
     * @memberOf _
     * @type Function
...
     */
```

I found this in association to a [TypeScript compiler issue](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/7002).

title: Implicit unwrapping of lodash objects
body:
When working extensively with lodash, one would sometimes like to pass around lodash wrapped objects as return values. Currently, this is inconvenient as lodash does no implicit unwrapping of the underlying value, forcing one to call .value() before returning.

Since lodash also supports lazy evaluation and shortcut fusion, large performance gains could also potentially be made if unwrapping was done lazily and implicitly.

Is there any good reason for not doing this? [lazy.js](https://github.com/dtao/lazy.js/) does this, for example.

title: functional forms of _.has/_.hasIn
body: Given how `_.matches` and `_.property` are so useful, I assumed there would be an equivalent for testing if a path exists in an object, but there don't seem to be one? Right now I'm doing something like `_.partial(_.has, _, 'a.b.c')` which is fine but just feels a bit verbose - if there is something more concise I'd love to know!

title: full vs. modular npm build
body:
I noticed that the npm build contains both [the entire lodash build](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/npm/lodash.js) ("main" of [`package.json`](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blob/npm/package.json)) and the [full set of modules](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/tree/npm).

I'm surprised that `lodash.js` doesn't just export all of the (public) modules -- is this a mistake?

It's atypical for npm packages, and has large implications for bundle sizes. If I depend on some libraries that do:

``` js
const map = require('lodash/map')
const reduce = require('lodash/reduce')
// etc.
```

But my project uses enough Lodash to warrant the convenience of:

``` js
const _ = require('lodash')
```

Then obviously I get all of Lodash in my bundle -- that's fine -- but I'd expect the lib imports to share code with my global import (s/o npm@3 deduping). Instead, my bundle contains (almost) the entire Lodash build twice.

(Sorry if this has been brought up -- couldn't find it in the issue history)

title: Run style checks before publishing
body:
As discussed in https://github.com/lodash/lodash/pull/1969, this will help
prevent style errors from creeping into our tagged releases.

title: (lodash/fp) findKey predicate receives key instead of object
fix FP rearg for zipWith and inRange
body: [2, 0, 1] seems like the more sensible default to me (there are 3 fewer exceptions, including the 2 this PR fixes) but I can revert this if you'd prefer.

title: Fix code style error and doc nit
body: Fix code style error introduced in 7811d59 and doc nit.

title: _.delta
body:
how about a delta function

`_.delta(arrayA, arrayB, addCallback, delCallback)`

compute additions and deletion between two arrays.

a = [1, 2, 3]
b = [3, 4, 5]

adds = [4, 5]
dels = [1, 2]

example usage: 

Imagine a multiple selection list scenario.  The selection list can change by addition or removal of items.  On each change, you want to add event listeners to newly added items, and remove previously added listeners from the ones no longer in the list.

title: Support for replacement in array
_.size does not return the actual size if an object has a key "length"
_.sortBy should mutate original array
body:
Like `Array.prototype.sort`, `_.sortBy` should mutate the original array.
I don't know if i'm missing something and why it not behave like this, maybe there's a way to do it?

title: [4.3.0] Debounce/Throttle inconsistent
body:
I've noticed that when updating to 4.3.0 my debounce and throttle functions were out of whack.

The first time they are called, they work properly. Any times after that, the function is invoked at the leading **and** trailing. Even if only called once.

I reverted back to 4.2.1 and everything is working properly.

title: Improve fp doc generation
body:
This is a follow-up to the work done in #1897, and adds a lot of changes to improve the signature of the methods and the examples in the generated docs.
I have compiled a list of changes in this [gist](https://gist.github.com/jfmengels/6b973b69c491375117dc), and the current result of the generation is available there too.

There is still a few things to do/fix (also listed in the gist, including converting the tests I wrote to QUnit), and ultimately, some examples will have to be adapted (either in this PR or later) because they won't make that much sense. For example: `pullAt`, `set`. Mostly the methods mutating the entry and therefore using console.logs(), and the examples that use too many arguments than are supported in fp.

Anyway, I was told it would be nice to share my progress, so there you go ;)

title: _.chunk with function like argument
added support for variable-depth flatten
body:
This commit adds an optional `maxDepth` argument to `_.flatten`, allowing a nested array to be recursively flattened to a variable degree.

Please double-check I made the correct change in fp/_mapping.js, because it was hard to tell what was going on in that file.

title: How to get rid of iterable methods (question v4)
body:
Updating from `v3` I noticed that when `_.omit` iterable methods are added to the value:

```
{
  ...
  get: [Function],
  values: [Function],
  keys: [Function],
  forEach: [Function],
  ...
}
```

Is there an option to not add those methods, or a method to get rid of them after omitting?
My `deepEqual` tests are failing because of that.

Also, why are they enumerable?

title: _.has not working with arrays
body:
`testvariable = {a: 'foo', b: 'foo', c: 'foo'}`

When I use `x = _.has(testvariable, ['a', 'b'])` the result is `false`. If I use `x = _.has(testvariable, 'a') and y = _.has(testvariable, 'b')` both x and y return `true`.

The documentation found on loadash.com indicates that I can use arrays when testing for properties. It therefore seems there is an issue with Lodash.

?

title: _.unzip is dropping values
body:
The following doesn't generate the expected output:

```
var DATA = _.unzip([
    [      +1.00111,      +0.00111,    -900.0000,       +0.0011,      +99.8890,    -90000.0000],
    [      +1.00118,      +0.00118     -850.0000,       +0.0011,      +99.8824,    -85000.0000],
    [      +1.0012,       +0.0012,     -800.0000,       +0.0012,      +99.8751,    -80000.0000]
]);

console.log(DATA[5][1]); // undefined
```

I've tested this with both 3.9.0 and 4.2.1 and get the same result. The full output shows other incorrect figures:

![developer_tools_-_http___localhost_45678_](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2337888/12884608/4be12988-ce57-11e5-96a1-61a1f0ade6f5.png)

title: _.merge behaves differently for undefined values in version 4.2.1 vs. 3.10.1
lodash vs. lodash/curry discrepancy
adds 'What to Use lodash for and When to Use It' section to README.md
body:
In an attempt to help make the lodash repository more approachable to a larger number of users — from informed developers to curious passersby and new and interested visitors like myself — I was curious if you would consider adding a new section to the lodash README that I wrote. It is entitled "What to Use lodash for and When to Use It". The intention is for the new section to provide a brief explanation, in relatively plain and straightforward language, of what lodash is used for and when one should use it.

As I am relatively new to all of this, I hope that I have made this inquiry in a proper and respectful manner. Thank you for your time and consideration. I am interested to hear your thoughts.

title: Non developer readme contribution
Improve accuracy of _.throttle
Support for insertion sorts
Upgrading from 3 to 4: array path for _.pluck does not work with _.map
body:
I'm not sure if this is a bug or a documentation issue.

``` js
objs = [{foo: {num: 1}}, {foo: {num: 3}}, {foo: {num: 100}}]

_.map(objs, 'foo.num') // as expected
// [1, 3, 100]

_.map(objs, ['foo', 'num']) // surprising
// [false, false, false]
```

In v3, `_.pluck(objs, ['foo', 'num'])` returned (correctly IMO) `[1, 3, 100]`.

However, `_.map(objs, ['foo', 'num'])` _is_ behaving consistently with v3.

The [changelog](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Changelog) only says

> Removed _.pluck in favor of _.map with iteratee shorthand

which implies that you do not need to change the arguments to pluck.

title: _.merge looses prototype of source object values
